link.title: How to Fix a Golf Hook: 7 Proven Drills and Fixes

entry.content:
How to Fix a Golf Hook: 7 Proven Drills and Fixes

A hook might feel better off the clubface than a slice—at least you’re hitting it solid—but a ball that starts right and dives left into the trees is just as costly as one that slices the other way.

The frustrating part? Many golfers develop a hook after they’ve fixed their slice, turning one problem into another. Let’s break down why hooks happen and how to straighten them out.

What Causes a Golf Hook?

A hook happens when the clubface is closed relative to your swing path at impact. Unlike a slice (open face + out-to-in path), a hook combines:

  • Clubface significantly closed to the target line
  • Swing path from inside (which is actually good—you just need to match face to path)

The ball starts right of your target (for right-handed golfers), then curves sharply left. The more closed the face relative to path, the more severe the curve.

Hook vs. Draw vs. Snap Hook

  • Draw: Slight right-to-left movement, lands near target
  • Hook: Excessive curve, misses left of target
  • Snap Hook / Duck Hook: Severe, low curve that dives quickly—often from an extremely closed face

The 7 Most Common Hook Causes

1. Grip Too Strong

The most frequent hook cause. When both hands rotate too far clockwise on the grip (for right-handers), the face naturally closes through impact.

Check yourself: Look down at your grip. If you can see 3-4 knuckles on your left hand, your grip is too strong.

The fix: Rotate both hands slightly counterclockwise until you see only 2 knuckles on your left hand. This feels weak at first but allows the face to stay more square.

2. Clubface Closed at Address

If you set up with the clubface already closed, you’re pre-programming a hook before you even swing.

Check yourself: At address, the leading edge should be perpendicular to your target line, not aimed left.

The fix: Use alignment sticks in practice. Set one for your target line and consciously square the face to it.

3. Overactive Hands Through Impact

Rolling your hands over too aggressively through the hitting zone closes the face rapidly. This often comes from the old advice to “release” the club, taken too far.

Check yourself: In slow-motion video, watch if your forearms rotate excessively through impact.

The fix: Practice the “logo up” drill—keep the logo on your glove facing the sky longer through impact.

4. Body Stalling, Hands Flipping

When your body rotation stops, your hands take over. Active hands without body rotation = rapid face closure.

Check yourself: At the finish, is your belt buckle facing the target? If not, you stalled.

The fix: Focus on continuous rotation through the ball. Feel like your chest beats your hands to the finish.

5. Ball Position Too Far Back

A ball positioned too far back in your stance forces you to catch it earlier in the swing arc—when the face is still closing.

Check yourself: For driver, ball should be just inside your lead heel. For irons, progressively more centered.

The fix: Use a ball position check in every practice session. Read our ball position guide for proper placement with each club.

6. Swing Path Too Far From Inside

An exaggerated inside-out path isn’t bad by itself—it’s what creates a draw. But when the face doesn’t match, you get hooks.

Check yourself: In video, does your club approach the ball from well inside? Do your divots point right?

The fix: You don’t necessarily need to change your path—just match your face to it better. A slightly more neutral path can also help.

7. Tension in Forearms and Hands

Grip pressure that’s too tight causes the forearms to activate, rotating the face closed.

Check yourself: Rate your grip pressure 1-10. If it’s above 4-5, you’re probably too tight.

The fix: Lighten your grip, especially with the trail hand. Sam Snead’s famous advice: hold the club like you’re holding a small bird.

7 Drills to Fix Your Hook

Drill 1: The Split-Grip Drill

Separate your hands 2-3 inches apart on the grip and hit short shots. This prevents the hands from rolling over too quickly.

How to do it:

  • Place your lead hand in normal position
  • Drop your trail hand 2-3 inches lower
  • Make 50-75% swings focusing on keeping the face stable

Drill 2: Glove Under Trail Arm

Tuck a glove or headcover under your trail armpit. If it falls before impact, you’re getting “disconnected”—which leads to flippy hands.

How to do it:

  • Tuck object under trail arm at address
  • Make swings keeping it in place through impact
  • Focus on body rotation rather than arm action

Drill 3: Alignment Stick in Belt Loop

Thread an alignment stick through your lead-side belt loop, pointing at the target. Through impact, rotate until the stick points left of target.

Why it works: Forces full body rotation, preventing the stall that causes hand flip.

Drill 4: Trail Arm Only Swings

Make slow-motion swings with just your trail hand. Focus on keeping the palm facing the sky longer through impact.

Why it works: Trains the trail arm to extend rather than rotate, which squares (rather than closes) the face.

Drill 5: Ball Position Check

Place two alignment sticks on the ground—one for target line, one perpendicular for ball position. Hit shots from correct positions for each club.

Why it works: Ensures you’re not positioning the ball too far back, which catches the face while it’s still closing.

Drill 6: The Pause Drill

Make a normal backswing, pause 2 seconds at the top, then swing through. This breaks the tension pattern that causes hooks.

Why it works: Eliminates the quick, handsy transition that throws timing off.

Drill 7: Aim the Handle Drill

At impact, focus on the butt of the club pointing at your belt buckle, not behind you. This keeps the face from closing too quickly.

Why it works: Maintains proper shaft angle through impact, preventing flip.

Common Mistakes When Fixing a Hook

Don’t Weaken Your Grip Too Much

Going from a strong grip to a weak grip often trades a hook for a slice. Make small adjustments—one knuckle at a time.

Don’t Aim Right to Compensate

Aiming right and playing the hook just grooves a bad pattern. Fix the cause instead of managing the symptom.

Don’t Forget the Cause Hierarchy

Check grip first, then setup, then swing. Most hooks start in the grip—you might not need to change your swing at all.

Using Video to Diagnose Your Hook

Recording your swing reveals what you can’t feel:

  1. Face-on view: Check ball position and hand rotation through impact
  2. Down-the-line view: Check swing path and face angle at address
  3. Slow motion: Watch forearm rotation through the hitting zone

Recording your swing with your phone takes 30 seconds and shows exactly why you’re hooking.

When to See a Professional

If you’ve tried these fixes for 3-4 practice sessions without improvement:

  • A lesson can identify your specific hook cause in minutes
  • Equipment fitting might reveal ill-fitted clubs (lie angle, shaft flex)
  • Custom fitting ensures your fixes aren’t fighting your equipment

When is it time for lessons?

Quick Reference: Hook Fix Checklist

Symptom Likely Cause First Fix
Low, diving hook Extremely closed face Check grip strength
High hook Closed face + path issue Ball position + rotation
Hook with driver only Driver setup different Ball forward + tee height
Hook with irons only Divots pointing right Match face to path
Inconsistent hooks Grip pressure changes Lighter, consistent grip

The Bottom Line

Hooks come from a clubface that’s closed relative to your swing path. Unlike slices, you already have the valuable inside-out path—you just need to match your face to it.

Start with the grip. More than half of hook problems are solved there. Then check ball position and setup before making swing changes. Small adjustments, made consistently, will straighten that hook into a controlled draw.

Android users have excellent options for golf swing analysis - you just need to know which apps actually work on your device.

The good news? Modern Android flagships (Samsung Galaxy, Pixel, OnePlus) have incredible cameras with slow-motion capabilities up to 960fps. The question is: which app takes full advantage of that hardware?

We tested 7 golf swing analyzer apps on Android and ranked them for real-world use. Here’s what we found.

App Best For Price AI Analysis Play Store Rating
Swing Analyzer Fast feedback Free tier Yes 4.7
V1 Golf Coach integration $99/yr Limited 4.5
18Birdies GPS + swing combo $99/yr Basic 4.4

Note: Sportsbox AI and Mustard Golf are iOS-only as of January 2026.

Our Top 3 Picks for Android

Best Overall: Swing Analyzer

Why it wins: 90-second AI analysis on any Android phone. No waiting hours for feedback - you get results while you’re still at the range. Works without a tripod, which matters when you don’t want to haul extra gear.

Key features:

  • Instant AI grading with letter grades (A-F)
  • Handicap prediction that’s surprisingly accurate
  • No tripod needed - works with phone propped up
  • Clean interface that doesn’t require a tutorial

Price: Free tier available, premium for advanced features

Best for: Android users who want immediate, actionable feedback without complexity.

Android note: Works smoothly on most devices running Android 10+. Optimized for Samsung Galaxy and Pixel cameras.

Try Swing Analyzer Free

Best for Coach Integration: V1 Golf

Why it’s great: The industry standard for lesson sharing. If your instructor uses V1 (most PGA pros do), this makes remote lessons seamless. The Android version has full feature parity with iOS.

Key features:

  • Drawing tools for swing markup
  • Split-screen comparison with tour pros
  • Voice-over lesson recordings
  • Shared libraries between student and coach

Price: $99/year

Best for: Golfers working with a teaching pro who want to share swings between sessions.

Limitation: AI analysis is basic - it’s designed for human coaches to add value.

Best Free Option: GolfFix AI

Why it’s great: Korean-developed app with a genuinely useful free tier. Detects 45+ swing issues using AI and is used in 63 countries. For $0, the analysis quality is impressive.

Key features:

  • Free AI swing analysis (not just a demo)
  • Detailed issue detection (early extension, casting, sway, etc.)
  • Before/after comparison tools
  • Works on mid-range Android devices

Price: Free (with optional premium upgrades)

Best for: Budget-conscious golfers who want AI analysis without paying.

Limitation: Interface isn’t as polished as premium options. Some features feel translated.

The Rest, Ranked

4. 18Birdies ($99/year)

Primarily a GPS rangefinder and stat tracker that includes swing analysis. Good if you want one app for everything on the course. The swing analyzer isn’t as deep as dedicated options, but the all-in-one value is solid.

Android note: Works well, though battery drain can be high with GPS running.

5. SWEE AI ($150/year)

Detailed metrics and clean interface. Requires a tripod setup for best results, which adds friction. Android version works but some users report occasional sync issues.

Android note: Performance varies by device. Works best on flagship phones.

6. Hudl Technique (Free)

Originally built for coaches across multiple sports. Excellent drawing and annotation tools. No AI analysis - you’re doing the work yourself. But if you just want slow-mo video with markup, it’s free and capable.

Android note: Reliable on most devices. Simple and lightweight.

7. Golf Swing Analyzer (Free)

Basic but functional. Records your swing and lets you draw lines on it. No AI, limited features, but it works. Good entry point if you’ve never used a swing analyzer.

Android note: Works on older Android devices where other apps struggle.

Android-Specific Considerations

Camera Quality Matters

Not all Android phones are equal. For best results:

Excellent: Samsung Galaxy S24/S23, Pixel 8 Pro, OnePlus 12 Good: Most 2023-2024 flagships from major brands Challenging: Budget phones with basic cameras

If your phone can shoot 240fps slow-motion (check your camera settings), you’ll get quality similar to iPhone. Many Samsung Galaxy phones can shoot at 960fps, which is actually superior.

Check Slow-Mo Settings

Before blaming an app:

  1. Open your camera app
  2. Switch to slow-motion mode
  3. Look for FPS settings (120, 240, 480, 960)
  4. Use at least 240fps for swing analysis

Many golfers use their Android’s slow-mo at 120fps, which is too choppy for proper analysis.

Storage Space

High-frame-rate videos eat storage fast. A 10-second swing at 240fps can be 100MB+. Make sure you have space, or the app will fail to save recordings.

How We Tested

We recorded the same swing with each app on a Samsung Galaxy S24 Ultra:

  • Outdoor range, natural lighting
  • 240fps slow-motion mode
  • Face-on and down-the-line angles
  • Same 12-handicap golfer

We evaluated:

  • Speed: How fast do you get feedback?
  • Accuracy: Do suggestions match what a pro would say?
  • Usability: Is the interface intuitive?
  • Value: Worth it for the average golfer?
  • Android stability: Crashes, bugs, device compatibility

What Android Apps Are Missing (iOS-Only)

Some popular options don’t have Android versions:

  • Sportsbox AI ($780/yr) - 3D biomechanics, iOS-only
  • Mustard Golf ($150/yr) - Drill recommendations, iOS-only
  • OnForm ($50/yr) - Lesson platform, iOS-only

If you need these specific features, iOS has an edge. But for most golfers, the Android options are more than sufficient.

Frequently Asked Questions

Which Android phones work best for golf swing analysis?

Samsung Galaxy S-series and Google Pixel are the best-supported. Any flagship from 2022+ will work well. Mid-range phones work but may have slower processing.

Do I need a tripod?

Depends on the app. Swing Analyzer, V1 Golf, and 18Birdies work fine propped up or handheld. SWEE AI really needs a tripod for best results. See our guide on recording your swing without a tripod for practical tips.

Why do some apps only work on iPhone?

Apple’s standardized hardware makes AI development easier. Android has thousands of device variations, so some developers skip it. The apps that do support Android well have invested in cross-platform compatibility.

Can I use the default camera app?

Yes! Your phone’s slow-mo camera works fine for self-review. But you won’t get AI analysis, drawing tools, or structured feedback. Apps add value on top of hardware.

Will these apps drain my battery?

Yes - video processing is intensive. Expect 15-20% battery use per hour of active recording and analysis. Bring a charger to the range.

The Bottom Line

For fast, practical feedback on Android: Swing Analyzer

If you work with a coach: V1 Golf

Best free option: GolfFix AI

All-in-one with GPS/stats: 18Birdies

Android users aren’t second-class citizens in golf tech. The best apps work great on your device - you just need to pick one that matches how you actually practice.

Start simple. See improvement. Then decide if you need more.

entry.title: Creating Lag in Your Golf Swing: The Secret to Effortless Power

link.title: Creating Lag in Your Golf Swing: The Secret to Effortless Power

entry.content:
Watch any tour pro in slow motion and you’ll see it: that angle between the lead arm and club shaft is preserved deep into the downswing. The club looks like it’s “lagging” behind the hands. Then, right before impact, it releases with explosive speed.

That’s lag. And it’s why professional golfers hit the ball 50+ yards farther than most amateurs—without looking like they’re swinging harder.

What Lag Actually Is

Lag is the angle between your lead arm and the club shaft during the downswing. At the top of a good backswing, this angle is roughly 90 degrees from proper wrist hinge. Maintaining that angle as you start down is what creates lag.

Here’s the key insight: lag isn’t something you create. It’s something you preserve.

During the backswing, your wrists naturally hinge as the club gets heavy. That creates the angle. The challenge is keeping that angle intact during the transition and early downswing, instead of losing it immediately.

When you maintain the angle, you store energy. When you release it at the right moment—just before impact—that stored energy transfers into the ball.

Why Amateur Golfers Lose Lag

The natural human instinct is to hit at the ball. When you see the ball and want to hit it hard, your body wants to throw the club at it immediately from the top.

This is called “casting” or “early release.” Instead of maintaining the wrist angle, you straighten your wrists right at the transition. The club releases too early, and all that stored energy dissipates before it reaches the ball.

Common causes of lost lag:

1. Upper body starting first

The proper downswing sequence is ground-up: lower body, torso, arms, then club. When your shoulders or arms initiate the downswing, the club tends to throw out immediately.

2. “Hitting” instead of “swinging”

The harder you try to hit the ball, the more you cast. Lag is actually easier to maintain when you swing at 80% effort with good sequence than when you swing all-out with bad sequence.

3. Grip pressure

Squeezing the club too tight prevents proper wrist hinge and makes early release more likely. A lighter grip allows the wrists to stay loaded longer.

4. No awareness

Many golfers don’t realize they’re losing lag. They feel like they’re “swinging hard” and don’t understand why they can’t generate tour-like distance. Video analysis reveals the truth.

The Feeling of Good Lag

Lag doesn’t feel like you’re actively holding an angle. It feels like the club is trailing behind your hands naturally as your body rotates toward the target.

Some useful feels:

  • Pulling the grip end toward the ball. Instead of throwing the clubhead at the ball, focus on pulling the handle. The head follows.

  • Keeping your back to the target longer. This creates space for the club to drop into the slot instead of casting over the top.

  • Delayed hit. Feel like you’re not even thinking about the ball until your hands are past hip height in the downswing.

None of these feels is literally what’s happening, but they create the right motion for most golfers.

Lag and Impact Position

Lag connects directly to impact position. When you maintain lag and release it at the right moment:

  • Your hands arrive ahead of the clubhead
  • The shaft leans forward toward the target
  • You compress the ball with descending contact
  • The clubhead reaches maximum speed right at impact—not before it

This is why lag produces both power and solid contact. The ball compresses against the face, and you get that satisfying “click” that means you hit it pure.

Golfers who cast lose both benefits. The club passes the hands before impact, the shaft leans backward, and contact becomes scoopy and thin.

How to Build Lag: Drills That Work

1. The Pump Drill

Start at the top of your backswing. Pump the club down to hip height while maintaining your wrist angle, then go back to the top. Do this three times, then hit the ball on the fourth pump.

This trains your body to sequence correctly: lower body first, arms and club following.

2. The Pause at the Top

Make a full backswing, then pause for a full second at the top. Feel your lower body start the downswing while your arms and club are still at the top.

This exaggerates the sequence separation that creates lag naturally.

3. Half-Speed Swings with Full Finish

Swing at 50% speed but focus on finishing in a full, balanced position. At half speed, you can feel the sequence better. Your hands should be well past hip height before you feel the club release.

Record these swings. You’ll see more lag at half speed than at full speed—that tells you what to work on.

4. The Glove Under the Arm Drill

Tuck a glove or headcover under your lead armpit. Make swings where it stays tucked through impact. This prevents your arms from flying away from your body early, which is often connected to casting.

5. Towel Whip Drill

Swing a towel like a golf club. To make the end “crack” like a whip, you can’t throw it from the top—you have to sequence properly and let the end accelerate late.

This teaches the feel of stored and released energy without a club.

What to Look for in Video

When you record your swing, freeze the video at these checkpoints:

Transition (just starting down):

  • The wrist angle should be similar to what it was at the top
  • Your hips should already be open (started rotating) while your shoulders are still relatively closed

Hands at hip height (downswing):

  • Look at the angle between your lead arm and the club shaft
  • Tour pros still have 70-90 degrees of lag here
  • Amateurs often have almost no angle left—the club has already straightened

At impact:

  • Hands should be ahead of the clubhead
  • Shaft leans toward the target
  • The wrist angle has released fully (the energy has been delivered)

Common Lag Myths

Myth: You should feel like you’re “holding” the lag.

Reality: Trying to hold the angle usually creates tension and awkward timing. Better players feel like they’re swinging freely, and lag happens naturally from good sequence.

Myth: More lag is always better.

Reality: There’s an optimal amount. Too much lag can actually cause timing issues and inconsistent contact. Focus on sequence, not maximizing the angle.

Myth: Lag requires a specific wrist condition.

Reality: Good lag comes from sequence and timing, not a particular wrist position. Both flat and slightly cupped lead wrists can produce excellent lag.

The Real Secret: It’s About Sequence

Lag is a result, not a cause. You don’t create lag by focusing on your wrists. You create lag by:

  1. Making a proper backswing with natural wrist hinge
  2. Starting the downswing from the ground up
  3. Letting your arms and club trail your body rotation
  4. Not trying to hit the ball—letting the release happen naturally

When the sequence is right, lag appears automatically. When you try to manufacture it, you usually make things worse.

That’s why video analysis is so valuable for working on lag. You can’t feel what’s actually happening in fractions of a second. But you can see it, frame by frame, and train the right patterns.

entry.title: How to Fix Early Extension in Your Golf Swing: 6 Proven Drills

link.title: How to Fix Early Extension in Your Golf Swing: 6 Proven Drills

entry.content:
Early extension is one of the most common and destructive swing flaws in golf. If you’ve ever hit a block to the right followed by a hook to the left, early extension might be the culprit. The good news? It’s fixable with the right understanding and drills.

What is Early Extension?

Early extension is any forward movement (thrust) of your lower body toward the golf ball during the downswing. Instead of rotating around a stable spine, your hips push toward the ball, forcing your torso to stand up and your arms to get “stuck” behind your body.

The result? Two frustrating misses:

  • The block (ball goes right) when your body outraces your arms
  • The hook (ball goes left) when your hands flip to compensate

Having two opposite misses makes consistent golf nearly impossible.

Why Early Extension Happens

Understanding the root causes helps you target the right fix:

Physical Limitations

  • Tight hips, hamstrings, or lower back - Research shows that any limitation in performing a full deep squat or hip bend can force early extension
  • Weak core muscles - Your core can’t stabilize your spine angle through impact
  • Poor mobility - You simply can’t maintain posture physically

Swing Mechanics

  • Open clubface at the top - Your body instinctively tries to close it by standing up
  • Over-the-top swing path - Creates a chain reaction of compensations
  • Improper weight transfer - Failure to shift weight correctly forces the thrust
  • Fear of the ground - Subconscious avoidance of hitting the turf

The Power Problem

Early extension doesn’t just hurt accuracy - it costs you distance. When your hips extend toward the ball, you lose the stored rotational power that should transfer to the clubhead. You’re essentially “spending” your power too early.

6 Proven Drills to Fix Early Extension

1. The Wall Drill (Chair Drill)

Setup: Stand with your backside touching a wall or chair back at address.

Execute: Make practice swings while maintaining contact with the wall throughout. Your glutes should stay against the wall from takeaway through impact.

Why it works: Forces your hips to rotate rather than thrust forward. You literally can’t early extend when your backside is anchored.

Reps: 20-30 slow practice swings, then hit balls with the same feeling.

2. The Head-on-Wall Drill

Setup: Stand as if addressing a ball with your forehead resting gently against a wall. No club needed.

Execute: Make slow-motion swing movements while keeping your forehead on the wall throughout.

Why it works: If you early extend, your head will push off the wall as your spine angle changes. This drill gives you immediate feedback on posture loss.

Reps: 15-20 repetitions, focusing on the feeling of maintaining spine angle.

3. The Trail Foot Torque Drill

Setup: Place a wedge under your trail foot (right foot for right-handers), standing on the clubface with the grip pointing up.

Execute: Make half-speed practice swings. Focus on keeping pressure on the wedge throughout.

Why it works: If you early extend, your heel lifts and the club falls. Proper hip rotation keeps the pressure on the club. This teaches you to use ground force correctly.

Reps: 10-15 swings, building awareness of proper lower body action.

4. The Split-Grip Drill

Setup: Hold the club with your hands separated - trail hand several inches below your lead hand on the grip.

Execute: Make half-swings and try to make contact with the ball.

Why it works: The separated grip position makes it nearly impossible to early extend and still hit the ball. Your spine is forced into the correct position through impact.

Reps: Hit 20 balls this way, then transition to normal grip with the same feeling.

5. The Two-Ball Drill

Setup: Place two golf balls side by side, about 2 inches apart. Set up to the outside ball.

Execute: Try to hit the inside ball.

Why it works: Made famous by instructor Monte Scheinblum, this drill forces you to stay back and rotate rather than thrust forward. If you early extend, you’ll hit the outside ball or miss entirely.

Reps: Hit 15-20 balls, focusing on the inside target.

6. The Belt Buckle Drill

Setup: Normal address position.

Execute: Focus on keeping your belt buckle pointing at or slightly behind the ball through impact. Feel like you’re “covering” the ball with your chest.

Why it works: This mental cue prevents the premature hip thrust. Your lower body can still rotate powerfully while maintaining spine angle.

Reps: Use this thought on every swing until it becomes automatic.

Physical Fixes for Early Extension

If your body is limiting your swing, these exercises help:

Flexibility Work

  • Hip flexor stretches - Lunge stretches, 30 seconds each side
  • Hip rotations - 10-15 circles each direction, both legs
  • Hamstring stretches - Essential for maintaining posture

Core Strengthening

  • Planks - Build the stability to hold your spine angle
  • Russian twists - Rotational core strength
  • Medicine ball throws - Power transfer through a stable core

Practice Tip

Before each range session, spend 5 minutes on hip mobility and a quick plank. Your body will be better prepared to maintain posture.

How to Know You’re Improving

Signs your early extension is getting better:

  1. More consistent miss direction - One-way misses are easier to manage
  2. Better ball striking - More center contact
  3. Hip rotation feels different - Spinning rather than thrusting
  4. Less back pain - Early extension stresses the lower back

Use Video to Track Progress

Early extension is hard to feel but easy to see. Recording your swing with your phone lets you see exactly what your hips are doing in the downswing.

Look for these checkpoints:

  • At address - Note your hip distance from the ball
  • At impact - Hips should be in the same position or slightly farther from the ball
  • Through impact - Rotation around spine, not thrust toward ball

Swing Analyzer can help you track your posture through the swing, giving you objective feedback on whether you’re maintaining your spine angle or early extending.

Common Mistakes When Fixing Early Extension

Don’t overcorrect by hanging back. Some golfers try so hard to avoid early extension that they keep their weight on the back foot. This causes fat shots and loss of power.

Don’t stop your hips. Early extension isn’t about stopping hip movement - it’s about the direction of movement. Your hips should rotate powerfully; they just shouldn’t thrust forward.

Don’t expect overnight fixes. Early extension is often a physical limitation combined with a swing habit. Both take time to change.

The Bottom Line

Early extension is fixable, but it requires understanding why you’re doing it:

  1. Physical limitations - Address mobility and strength
  2. Swing mechanics - Use drills to groove proper movement
  3. Video feedback - You can’t fix what you can’t see

Start with the Wall Drill and Split-Grip Drill - they give the most immediate feedback. Add the physical work if flexibility is an issue. And use video analysis to track your progress.

Your lower back will thank you, and your consistency will improve dramatically once you stop thrusting toward the ball.

Struggling to see your own early extension? Swing Analyzer provides instant AI-powered feedback on your swing, including posture throughout the motion. Try it free and see exactly what your hips are doing.
entry.summary: Early extension is destroying your consistency. Learn what causes this common swing flaw, why it leads to blocks and hooks, and 6 proven drills to fix it for good.

entry.title: How to Fix an Over-the-Top Golf Swing: Causes and Drills That Work

link.title: How to Fix an Over-the-Top Golf Swing: Causes and Drills That Work

entry.content:
The over-the-top move is the #1 swing flaw among amateur golfers. It causes slices, pulls, weak contact, and endless frustration. But here’s the good news: it’s fixable with the right understanding and drills.

What Does “Over the Top” Mean?

Coming over the top means your club moves outside the ideal swing path during the downswing. Instead of dropping the club into the “slot” on an inside path, you throw it outward toward the ball. The result is a steep, out-to-in swing that produces:

  • Slices (ball curves hard right for right-handed golfers)
  • Pulls (ball starts left and stays left)
  • Weak pop-ups with the driver
  • Deep divots pointing left
  • Loss of distance and consistency

If you’re hitting pulls with short irons and slices with longer clubs, over the top is almost certainly your issue.

The Root Causes

Understanding why you come over the top is essential to fixing it. The main culprits:

1. Arms Dominate the Downswing

The most common cause. Instead of letting your lower body lead, you start the downswing by throwing your arms at the ball. This immediately pushes the club outside the proper path.

2. Poor Weight Transfer

If you stay stuck on your back foot, your body can’t rotate through properly. The arms have nowhere to go except over the top.

3. Early Hip Spin (Instead of Bump)

Some golfers spin their hips too early without shifting forward first. This stalls rotation and forces an over-the-top compensation.

4. Too Much Wrist Extension at the Top

An excessively “cupped” wrist at the top can preset an over-the-top path. The club face opens, and you instinctively throw from outside to square it.

5. Wrong Mental Picture

Many golfers think they need to hit “down” on the ball, which creates a steep, outside attack. The reality is the club should approach from inside.

7 Drills to Fix Over the Top

1. Headcover Drill

Setup: Place a headcover 6-8 inches behind the ball, just outside your target line.

Execution: On the downswing, feel your arms swing under the headcover. Your chest should stay “closed” longer as the club drops inside.

Success check: If you hit the headcover, you came over the top. Keep practicing until you consistently miss it.

Why it works: Creates a visual barrier that forces you to find the inside path.

2. Trail Foot Flare

Setup: Flare your trail foot (right foot for righties) 15-25 degrees open at address.

Execution: Make your normal swing. The flared foot allows your hips to rotate more freely.

Why it works: Improved hip rotation creates more depth in your backswing, making it easier to drop the club inside on the downswing.

This is one of the simplest fixes—sometimes a setup change is all you need.

3. Hip Bump with Alignment Stick

Setup: Place an alignment stick vertically in the ground. Position your front hip about an inch away from it at address.

Execution: On the downswing, “bump” your front hip into the stick before your arms swing through.

Success check: You should feel your hip touch the stick before the club reaches the ball.

Why it works: Forces proper sequencing—lower body leads, arms follow. This creates space for an inside path.

4. Ball Throwing Drill

Setup: Hold a golf ball in your trail hand (right hand for righties).

Execution: Make a backswing motion, then throw the ball underhand as if skipping it on water to your right (at 90 degrees from your target line).

Success check: If the ball flies straight ahead or left, you’re coming over the top. Work until it naturally releases to the right.

Why it works: Teaches the feel of proper arm rotation and path without a club.

5. Pump Drill

Setup: Take your normal address position.

Execution: Make a backswing, then “pump” the club down halfway three times without hitting the ball. Feel the club drop into the slot each time. On the fourth pump, complete the swing.

Why it works: Builds muscle memory for the correct downswing initiation. The pumping motion reinforces the inside drop.

6. Feet Together Drill

Setup: Address an 8-iron with your feet completely together.

Execution: Make half to three-quarter swings, hitting balls toward a target 75-100 yards away.

Why it works: With feet together, you can’t throw your body at the ball. Forces proper arm path and timing. If you come over the top with feet together, you’ll lose balance immediately.

7. Pause at the Top

Setup: Normal address position.

Execution: Complete your backswing, pause for a full second at the top, then start down slowly with your hips before accelerating through impact.

Why it works: The pause breaks the habit of rushing from the top with your arms. It gives you time to feel the lower body initiate.

The Fix in Practice

When working on your over-the-top move:

  1. Start without a ball — Make dozens of slow practice swings feeling the inside path
  2. Use half swings first — The shorter swing makes it easier to feel the correct sequence
  3. Record your swing — Swing Analyzer can show you exactly where your club path is at each point
  4. One drill at a time — Pick the drill that gives you the best “feel” and commit to it
  5. Be patient — This flaw took years to develop; it won’t disappear in one range session

Check Your Divots

Your divot tells the truth. If your divot points left of target (for right-handed golfers), you’re still coming over the top. A neutral or slightly right-pointing divot indicates you’ve found an inside path.

See our guide on reading divot patterns for more on this diagnostic tool.

The Connection to Your Slice

If you slice the ball, over the top is likely the culprit. Check out our detailed guide on how to fix a golf slice for more drills and fixes specific to eliminating the slice.

The over-the-top move and the slice are closely related, but not identical. You can come over the top and hit pulls (face closed) or slices (face open). Fixing the path is step one; face control is step two.

Video Analysis Helps

One of the best ways to track your progress is recording your swing from down the line. This angle clearly shows whether your club is dropping inside or thrown outside. Learn how to record your swing for accurate self-analysis.

Modern apps like Swing Analyzer can trace your club path and show you exactly where the over-the-top move happens, making it easier to target your practice.

Summary

The over-the-top swing is common but fixable. Key points:

  • It’s a sequencing issue — arms fire before lower body
  • Multiple causes — identify yours for targeted improvement
  • Drills work — but commit to one or two rather than trying everything
  • Record your progress — video doesn’t lie
  • Patience required — ingrained habits take time to change

With consistent practice using these drills, you can eliminate the over-the-top move and start hitting straighter, more powerful shots.

Ready to see your swing path in detail? Try Swing Analyzer for AI-powered feedback on your downswing sequence and club path.
entry.summary: Stop slicing and pulling shots with this complete guide to fixing your over-the-top golf swing. Learn the root causes and 7 proven drills to get your club on the right path.

entry.title: Golf Ball Position Guide: Where to Place the Ball for Every Club

link.title: Golf Ball Position Guide: Where to Place the Ball for Every Club

entry.content:
Ball position might be the most overlooked fundamental in golf. You spend hours perfecting your swing, but if the ball is in the wrong spot at address, you are fighting a losing battle before the club even moves.

The good news? Once you understand where to place the ball for each club, you will make better contact immediately. No swing changes required.

Why Ball Position Matters

Ball position directly affects three critical factors in your shot:

Contact Quality: Position the ball too far forward and you will catch it thin or top it entirely. Too far back and you will chunk it into the turf. The correct position puts the ball exactly where your swing naturally bottoms out.

Launch Angle and Trajectory: Forward ball positions create higher launch. Back positions create lower, more penetrating shots. This is physics, not opinion.

Shot Shape: Ball position influences whether you hit draws or fades. A ball too far forward tends to produce pulls and hooks. Too far back leads to pushes and slices.

Understanding these relationships lets you dial in consistent contact and predictable ball flight. It also gives you tools to adjust trajectory when conditions demand it.

Ball Position for Every Club in Your Bag

Here is your complete reference guide, starting with the longest clubs and working down to wedges.

Driver: Inside Your Front Heel

Your driver requires the most forward ball position of any club. Place the ball just inside your front heel, opposite your big toe on the lead foot.

Why so far forward? The driver is the only club you want to hit on the upswing. That ascending strike launches the ball higher with less spin, maximizing distance. Position it too far back and you will hit down on it, creating excess spin and losing yards.

A common mistake is playing the driver too far forward, past the front heel. This causes topped shots, pop-ups, and hooks as you reach for the ball at impact.

For more on optimizing your tee shots, check out our guide to hitting longer, straighter drives.

Fairway Woods and Hybrids: One to Two Balls Back

Fairway woods and hybrids sit about one to two ball widths back from your driver position. This puts them roughly opposite the logo on your shirt or just inside your front armpit.

These clubs need a slightly descending or level strike. You want to sweep the ball cleanly off the turf or tee. Too far forward and you will catch them thin. Too far back and you will dig into the ground before making contact.

Hybrids are particularly sensitive to ball position. Many golfers play them too far back like an iron, which causes fat shots. Keep them closer to your fairway wood position and let the club design do its job.

Long Irons (3-5 Iron): Center-Forward

Long irons should sit about one to two inches forward of center, roughly in line with your shirt logo or the inside of your front armpit.

You need a descending blow with irons, but long irons require a shallower angle of attack than short irons. This forward position lets you compress the ball while still catching it cleanly.

If you struggle with long irons, ball position is often the culprit. Move it too far back and you will never get these clubs airborne consistently.

Mid Irons (6-7 Iron): Just Forward of Center

Your mid irons belong about one inch forward of the center of your stance. Think of a spot between your sternum and shirt logo.

This position promotes the ball-first contact that creates that satisfying divot after the ball. You are hitting down through the shot, compressing the ball against the turf for maximum control.

Short Irons and Wedges (8-Iron through Lob Wedge): Center

Short irons and wedges should be positioned at or very near the center of your stance. Some players prefer them slightly back of center for even more control.

These clubs demand the steepest angle of attack. Center position lets you drive down through the ball aggressively, creating the backspin that stops shots on the green.

For specialty wedge shots around the green, you might move the ball slightly back for lower trajectories or forward for higher, softer landings.

Common Ball Position Mistakes

Even experienced golfers fall into these traps. Here is what to watch for.

Ball Too Far Forward

When the ball creeps too far forward in your stance, several bad things happen:

  • Thin shots: Your swing arc bottoms out before reaching the ball, catching it on the upswing with the leading edge
  • Pulls and hooks: You have to release the club early to reach the ball, closing the face through impact
  • Loss of compression: You cannot hit down on the ball properly, losing distance and control

If you are hitting thin shots and pulls, check your ball position first. It is probably too far forward for the club in your hands.

Our guide on fixing fat and thin shots covers this in detail.

Ball Too Far Back

The opposite problem creates its own set of issues:

  • Fat shots: Your swing bottoms out before the ball, driving the club into the turf
  • Pushes and blocks: You cannot square the face in time, leaving it open at impact
  • Low trajectory: You deloft the club excessively, hitting line drives when you need height

Fat shots and pushes often trace back to ball position that has drifted too far back.

Inconsistent Position

Perhaps the biggest mistake is not having a consistent ball position at all. Many golfers eyeball it differently every time, creating random contact patterns.

Your brain cannot learn to time impact correctly if the ball moves around. Establish consistent reference points and use them every single time you address a shot.

How to Check Your Ball Position

Guessing leads to inconsistency. Here are two proven methods to verify your ball position.

The Alignment Stick Drill

This is the gold standard for ball position practice:

  1. Place an alignment stick on the ground pointing at your target
  2. Place a second stick perpendicular to the first, running between your feet
  3. Position the ball where the sticks intersect
  4. Step into your stance and check where the ball sits relative to your feet

The perpendicular stick shows you exactly where center is. From there, you can accurately measure forward or back positions for different clubs.

Use this drill regularly on the range until correct positions become automatic. For more on using alignment aids effectively, see our complete alignment guide.

The Foot-Check Method

For a quick check without equipment:

  1. Address the ball as normal
  2. Without moving your feet, bring your hands together in front of your body
  3. Let your hands hang naturally from your shoulders
  4. Look down and note where your hands point relative to the ball

Your hands naturally hang at the center of your stance. If the ball is forward of your hands, it is forward of center. If it is behind your hands, it is back of center.

This works great for mid-round adjustments when you cannot lay down alignment sticks.

Ball Position for Special Situations

Standard positions work for flat lies and normal conditions. But golf rarely gives you perfect circumstances.

Uphill Lies

On uphill lies, move the ball slightly forward in your stance. The slope effectively tilts your swing arc forward, so the ball needs to move with it.

Also widen your stance for stability and expect higher trajectory with less distance.

Downhill Lies

Downhill lies require the opposite adjustment. Move the ball back in your stance to account for the slope tilting your swing arc backward.

Expect lower trajectory and more roll. Take one less club and plan for the ball to run.

Windy Conditions

When you need to flight the ball lower into the wind, move it back in your stance by one to two ball widths. This naturally delofts the club and produces a more penetrating trajectory.

Combine this with a shorter backswing and smooth tempo. Fighting the wind with a harder swing just creates more spin and balloons the shot higher.

Tight Lies

On hardpan or tight lies where there is no grass cushion, play the ball slightly back of your normal position. This steeper angle of attack helps you catch the ball cleanly without bouncing the club off the hard surface.

Building Your Pre-Shot Routine

Ball position should be part of a consistent pre-shot routine. Here is a simple approach:

  1. Stand behind the ball and pick your target line
  2. Walk to the ball from the side, setting the clubface first
  3. Position your feet using a consistent reference point
  4. Take one look at the target and swing

The key is making ball position automatic, not something you think about over every shot. Build it into your routine and trust it.

The Bottom Line

Correct ball position is not complicated, but it demands attention. Here is your quick reference:

  • Driver: Inside front heel
  • Fairway woods and hybrids: One to two balls back from driver
  • Long irons: Center-forward
  • Mid irons: Just forward of center
  • Short irons and wedges: Center

Get these positions dialed in and you will make better contact without changing anything else in your swing. That is the kind of improvement every golfer can use.

See Your Ball Position at Address

Want to verify your ball position is correct? Swing Analyzer’s video analysis shows you exactly where the ball sits relative to your stance at address. Upload a face-on video and see your setup from a perspective you cannot get on your own. In 90 seconds, you will know if ball position is helping or hurting your swing.

Ball position affects everything from contact to trajectory to shot shape. Get it right and the rest of your swing has a chance to work. Get it wrong and you are compensating before the club even moves.
entry.summary: Learn the correct golf ball position for driver, irons, and wedges. Master ball placement to improve contact, trajectory, and distance on every shot.

entry.title: Golf Course Management: The Smart Strategy Guide to Lower Scores

link.title: Golf Course Management: The Smart Strategy Guide to Lower Scores

entry.content:
Here’s a humbling statistic: according to Shot Scope data, average recreational golfers miss greens short 54% of the time. Not left. Not right. Not long. Short.

This isn’t a swing problem—it’s a course management problem. Most amateurs don’t know their true distances, overestimate their abilities, and compound these errors with poor target selection.

The fastest way to drop 3-5 strokes from your scores isn’t a new swing thought—it’s smarter decision-making on every shot.

What Is Course Management?

Course management is the art of making decisions that maximize your scoring probability. It includes:

  • Club selection based on realistic distances
  • Target picking that accounts for your tendencies
  • Risk-reward assessment on every shot
  • Recovery strategy when things go wrong
  • Mental approach throughout the round

The best course managers aren’t always the best ball-strikers. They simply avoid mistakes that turn pars into bogeys and bogeys into doubles.

The Foundation: Know Your True Distances

Most scoring leaks stem from distance delusion. Here’s how to build an honest distance chart.

Carry Distance vs. Total Distance

Your carry distance is what matters for course management—total distance includes roll, which varies by conditions. Track carry, not total.

Real Yardages, Not Best-Case Scenarios

Stop measuring distances from your career-best shots. Tour pros base club selection on their 80th percentile distance—the distance they hit or exceed 80% of the time.

Your real 7-iron isn’t that one time you caught it pure on a downhill lie with helping wind. It’s what you hit when you’re slightly off-center, which is most swings.

Building Your Distance Chart

Spend a range session tracking actual carry distances:

Club Your Carry (Example)
PW _____ 120 yards
9i _____ 130 yards
8i _____ 140 yards
7i _____ 150 yards
6i _____ 160 yards
5i _____ 170 yards

Use a launch monitor or GPS app to get accurate numbers. AI golf swing analyzers can also track your distances over time. Once you know your real distances, club selection becomes simple math instead of hopeful guessing.

Why You Miss Greens Short

The 54% short miss rate comes from several compounding errors:

1. Distance Overestimation

Most golfers think they hit clubs 10-15 yards farther than they actually do. A golfer who thinks their 7-iron goes 160 yards but actually carries 145 will miss short constantly.

2. Middle-of-Green Aiming

When the pin is back, aiming at the center of the green is actually aiming short of the hole. Your “miss” is programmed in before you swing.

3. Failure to Account for Conditions

Cold air, elevation, wind, and humidity all affect distance. A shot that carries 150 yards in summer might only go 140 in cold weather.

4. Safety Bias

Golfers subconsciously fear going long (often there’s trouble behind greens), so they unconsciously take off power. The result: consistent short misses.

The Fix: Pick a club that gets you to the back of the green on a centered strike. If you catch it slightly thin, you still hit the putting surface. If you pure it, you’re on the back—but still on.

Target Selection: Where You Aim Matters

Don’t Aim at Flags—Aim at Zones

Pin-seeking from 150 yards is ego golf. Tour pros aim at specific quadrants of greens based on:

  • Pin location
  • Miss tendency
  • Green contours
  • Surrounding hazards

As an amateur, your target should usually be the fat part of the green. A 30-foot putt beats a chip from a bunker every time.

Account for Your Curve

If you typically fade the ball 10 yards, your aim point needs to be 10 yards left of your target. Yet most golfers aim at the target and watch the ball curve into trouble.

Right-handed fader: Aim at the left third of the green Right-handed drawer: Aim at the right third of the green

Your curve is a feature, not a bug—but only if you account for it.

Danger Zone Mapping

Before each approach, identify:

  1. Where is the worst miss? (deep bunker, water, OB)
  2. Where is the acceptable miss? (fringe, shallow rough)
  3. What aim point eliminates the worst outcome?

The goal isn’t a perfect shot—it’s eliminating disaster.

The Risk-Reward Framework

Every shot involves a risk-reward calculation. Smart golfers make conscious choices instead of hoping for the best.

The 60% Rule

Only attempt a shot if you can execute it successfully at least 60% of the time. This includes:

  • Carrying that bunker on a 220-yard approach
  • Threading between trees on a recovery shot
  • Going for a par-5 in two

If you’d fail more often than you’d succeed, take the safer option.

Par-5 Math

Going for the green in two feels heroic, but let’s examine the math:

Aggressive play (going for it):

  • 30% chance of reaching green, average result = birdie (4)
  • 40% chance of just missing, average result = par (5)
  • 30% chance of hazard/trouble, average result = bogey+ (6+)
  • Expected score: ~5.1

Conservative play (laying up):

  • 80% chance of 100-yard wedge approach
  • Average result = par/bogey (5.2)
  • No blow-up potential
  • Expected score: ~5.2

The numbers are closer than you’d think—and conservative play has lower variance. Save aggressive plays for when you’re actually hot.

When to Take Risk

  • You’re significantly behind in match play
  • Wind or conditions favor the aggressive line
  • The “safe” play isn’t actually safe
  • You’re in a good mental state and playing well

When to Play Safe

  • Any time the risk is OB or water
  • You haven’t been striking it well
  • The hole is playing hard for the field
  • One mistake ends your round (tournament golf)

Tee Shot Strategy

Driver Isn’t Always Right

The goal of a tee shot is positioning for the approach, not maximum distance. Consider:

  • What distance leaves your favorite approach yardage?
  • Is driver’s extra distance worth its extra dispersion?
  • Where is the trouble, and what club avoids it?

On a 380-yard hole with trouble at 260 yards, a 240-yard 3-wood leaves 140 yards—a controlled 8-iron. Driver might leave 100 yards, but if one miss puts you in hazard or trees, the 3-wood is smarter.

Picking Your Side

Tee boxes let you choose your angle. If trouble is right:

  • Tee up on the right side
  • Aim away from trouble
  • Your natural curve should turn away from danger

Most amateurs tee up randomly. Pros are intentional about every setup variable.

Recovery Strategy

You’ll hit bad shots. Course management determines whether they become bogeys or double-bogeys.

The Golden Rule of Recovery

Get the ball back in play. Period.

The hero shot from trouble that looks cool on TV? Tour pros attempt those because they execute them. Your job is to minimize damage and give yourself a chance at bogey.

The 90-Degree Rule

When you’re in trees or trouble, the first priority is getting out—even if that means going sideways or slightly backwards. A 90-degree punch to the fairway beats a tree-ricocheting attempt that leaves you in more trouble.

Calculate Your Real Options

From trouble, honestly assess:

  1. What’s the probability I can advance toward the green?
  2. What happens if I miss the tight window?
  3. Is there a 100% escape route that sets up a short-game opportunity?

Taking medicine early (accepting one stroke of penalty) often saves two or three strokes compared to compounding errors.

Mental Course Management

Process Over Outcome

Developing a solid pre-shot routine helps you execute good decisions consistently. You can make a great decision and hit a good shot that yields a bad result (wind gust, unlucky bounce). Conversely, you can make a terrible decision and get lucky.

Judge your course management by your process, not individual outcomes. Over time, good process yields good results.

The Fresh-Start Mentality

After a bad hole, many golfers press harder on the next one—trying to “get the stroke back.” This leads to aggressive decisions and more mistakes.

Each hole is independent. Your previous result doesn’t change the optimal strategy for the current shot. Reset mentally.

Pre-Round Preparation

Before your round:

  1. Review the scorecard and note tricky holes
  2. Identify where trouble is (course map or GPS)
  3. Plan your tee shot strategy for each hole
  4. Note which holes you’ll play aggressively vs. conservatively

Having a plan removes in-the-moment emotional decisions.

Putting Course Management in Practice

Practice Rounds

During casual rounds, experiment with course management:

  • Hit 3-wood instead of driver and note results
  • Aim at green centers instead of pins
  • Take the safe option on every risk-reward hole
  • Track how often you avoid big numbers

Shot Tracking

Record decisions, not just scores:

  • What club did you hit?
  • What was your target?
  • What was the result?
  • Was the decision smart given the outcome?

Patterns emerge: maybe you succeed 70% when going for it from 200 yards but only 30% from 230 yards. Data drives better future decisions.

Using Technology

Modern golf swing analyzer apps and GPS apps provide data that supports better course management:

  • Accurate carry distances from practice
  • Hole layouts with hazard distances
  • Shot tracking and pattern analysis

The same technology that analyzes your swing can help you make smarter choices on the course.

The Course Management Mindset

Playing smart golf isn’t boring golf—it’s winning golf. The most satisfying rounds often involve fewer spectacular shots and more solid, boring pars.

When you stop trying to manufacture career-best shots on every swing and start maximizing your probability of scoring well, you’ll discover a new level of consistency. And lower scores.

The next time you reach for driver on a tight hole or aim at a sucker pin, pause. Ask yourself: what decision gives me the best chance to walk off this green with a good number?

That’s course management—and it might be the fastest improvement tool in your bag.
